raw_text: Our approach builds upon earlier work on corpus-based methods for generating extraction patterns (Riloff, 1996b) and semantic lexicons (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997)
clean_text: Our approach builds upon earlier work on corpus-based methods for generating extraction patterns (Riloff, 1996b) and semantic lexicons (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997).

raw_text: ~ The corpus-based algorithm that we used to build the semantic lexicon (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) requires five& quot; seed words& quot; as input for each semantic category, and produces a ranked list of words that are statistically associated with each category
clean_text: The corpus-based algorithm that we used to build the semantic lexicon (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) requires five seed words as input for each semantic category, and produces a ranked list of words that are statistically associated with each category.

raw_text: For more details of this algorithm, see (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997)
clean_text: For more details of this algorithm, see (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997).

raw_text: In addition, we exploit syntactic constructions shown to be useful by other studies? list sand conjunctions (Roark and Charniak, 1998), and adjacent words (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997)
clean_text: In addition, we exploit syntactic constructions shown to be useful by other studies - lists and conjunctions (Roark and Charniak, 1998), and adjacent words (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997).

raw_text: (Hearst, 1992), Snowball (Agichtein and Gravano, 2000), AutoSlog (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997), and Junto (Talukdar, 2010) among others, also have similarities to our approach
clean_text: (Hearst, 1992), Snowball (Agichtein and Gravano, 2000), AutoSlog (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997), and Junto (Talukdar, 2010) among others, also have similarities to our approach.

raw_text: 771Riloff and Shepherd (1997) used a semi automatic method for discovering similar words using a few seed examples by using pattern-based techniques and human supervision
clean_text: Riloff and Shepherd (1997) used a semi automatic method for discovering similar words using a few seed examples by using pattern-based techniques and human supervision.

raw_text: For ex ample, Riloff and Shepherd (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) developed a statistical co-occurrence model for semantic lexicon induction that was designed with these structures in mind
clean_text: For example, Riloff and Shepherd (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) developed a statistical co-occurrence model for semantic lexicon induction that was designed with these structures in mind.

raw_text: Many of the successful methods follow the unsupervised it era tive bootstrapping framework (Riloff and Shepherd,1997)
clean_text: Many of the successful methods follow the unsupervised iterative bootstrapping framework (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997).

raw_text: NLP researchers have developed many algorithms for mining knowledge from text and the Web, including facts (Etzioni et al 2005) ,semantic lexicons (Riloff and Shepherd 1997), concept lists (Lin and Pantel 2002), and word similarity lists (Hindle 1990)
clean_text: NLP researchers have developed many algorithms for mining knowledge from text and the Web, including facts (Etzioni et al 2005), semantic lexicons (Riloff and Shepherd 1997), concept lists (Lin and Pantel 2002), and word similarity lists (Hindle 1990).

raw_text: The idea here is that nouns in conjunctions or appositives tend to be semantically related, as discussed in Riloff and Shepherd (1997) and Roark and Charniak (1998)
clean_text: The idea here is that nouns in conjunctions or appositives tend to be semantically related, as discussed in Riloff and Shepherd (1997) and Roark and Charniak (1998).

raw_text: Both Hearst (1992) and Riloff and Shepherd (1997) use unparsed text
clean_text: Both Hearst (1992) and Riloff and Shepherd (1997) use unparsed text.

raw_text: Riloff and Shepherd (1997) suggested using conjunction and appositive data to cluster nouns; however, they approximated this data by just looking at the nearest NP on each side of a particular NP
clean_text: Riloff and Shepherd (1997) suggested using conjunction and appositive data to cluster nouns; however, they approximated this data by just looking at the nearest NP on each side of a particular NP.

raw_text: The underlying claim is that words which are semantically similar occur with similar distributions and in similar con texts (Miller and Charles, 1991) .The main results to date in the field of automatic lexical acquisition are concerned with extracting lists of words reckoned to belong together in a particular category, such as vehicles or weapons (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) (Roarkand Charniak, 1998)
clean_text: The main results to date in the field of automatic lexical acquisition are concerned with extracting lists of words reckoned to belong together in a particular category, such as vehicles or weapons (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) (Roark and Charniak, 1998).

raw_text: for category membership and output a ranked list Algorithms of this type were used by Riloff and Shepherd (1997) and Roark and Charniak (1998), reporting accuracies of 17% and 35% respectively
clean_text: Algorithms of this type were used by Riloff and Shepherd (1997) and Roark and Charniak (1998), reporting accuracies of 17% and 35% respectively.

raw_text: Since lists are usually comprised of objects which are similar in some way, these relationships have been used to extract lists of nouns with similar properties (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) (Roarkand Charniak, 1998)
clean_text: Since lists are usually comprised of objects which are similar in some way, these relationships have been used to extract lists of nouns with similar properties (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) (Roarkand Charniak, 1998).

raw_text: These conditions are at least as stringent as those of previous experiments, particularly those of Riloff and Shepherd (1997) who also give credit for words associated with but not belonging to a particular category
clean_text: These conditions are at least as stringent as those of previous experiments, particularly those of Riloff and Shepherd (1997) who also give credit for words associated with but not belonging to a particular category.

raw_text: Our results are an order of magnitude better than those reported by Riloff and Shepherd (1997) and Roark and Charniak (1998), who report average accuracies of 17% and 35% respectively
clean_text: Our results are an order of magnitude better than those reported by Riloff and Shepherd (1997) and Roark and Charniak (1998), who report average accuracies of 17% and 35% respectively.

raw_text: The experiments in (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) were performed on the 500,000 word MUC-4 corpus, and those of (Roark and Charniak, 1998) were performed using MUC-4 and the Wall Street Journalcor pus (some 30 million words)
clean_text: The experiments in (Riloff and Shepherd, 1997) were performed on the 500,000 word MUC-4 corpus, and those of (Roark and Charniak, 1998) were performed using MUC-4 and the Wall Street Journal corpus (some 30 million words).
